Award.AwardTitle: Multi-scale geometry of bi-Lipschitz and quasiconformal maps
Award.AbstractNarration:
The notion of distance is fundamental both to human perception of the physical space around us, and to the idealization of this space in geometry. The distillation of the most salient properties of distance leads to the concept of a metric space.
Applications of this concept abound in computer science, machine learning, mathematical genetics, statistics and other disciplines where quantitative dissimilarity of objects is of interest. A proper way to understand metric spaces is to consider their transformations that shrink or stretch the distance on the space by a bounded amount. These are called bi-Lipschitz transformations, and they are at the focus of the proposed investigation. As an example of an application of such transformations, one can mention that accurate representations of a given, possibly quite irregular, metric space within a Euclidean space is an essential aspect of data visualization and analysis.

Normed linear spaces provide a convenient model to which less regular metric spaces can be compared. Thus, it is of interest to know when a given metric space is bi-Lipschitz equivalent to a normed space, or can be embedded into one. This is one of the principal problems addresses in the proposal. Even for two-dimensional spaces (metric planes) our understanding of bi-Lipschitz equivalence is far from complete. One approach to this problem is to introduce and study numeric invariants of metric spaces, such as dimension-type concepts which capture the size or degree of connectivity within the space. A different, but related approach involves analytic properties of functions supported on the space: Poincare inequality and various extension properties (Sobolev, Lipschitz, etc). The proposal involves both of these approaches. In particular, the quantitative aspects of the bi-Lipschitz extension problem will be investigated.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

The concept of a metric space, that is a collection of arbitrary objects with a notion of distance between them, is one of fundamental mathematical structures. One can understand the geometry of metric spaces by considering their transformations that preserve or nearly preserve the distances between points. For example, under a Lipschitz transformation the distances do not increase by more than a numeric factor, called the Lipschitz constant. The existence or non-existence of Lipschitz maps with additional properties, such as invertibility, gives us an insight of how similar two metric spaces are. The results of this project show that in certain geometrically natural contexts, such as a transformation from a circle into a plane, an invertible Lipschitz map can be extended to an invertible Lipschitz map of the region bounded by the circle, at the cost of increasing the Lipschitz constant by only a fixed factor independent of the map.


Every metric space carries an additional structure called finite subset spaces: they consist of finite subsets of a metric space. For example, the finite subset space of a familiar 3-dimensional Euclidean space is the collection of all "point clouds" in it, each consisting of some finite number of points. Point clouds are ubiquitous in data analysis. A primary task involved in studying point clouds (finite subsets) is reducing their complexity - for example, by identifying clusters within a cloud. A mathematical interpretation of the clustering process is a transformation from (at most) n-point subsets to (at most) k-point subsets where k is less than n. Such a transformation should be Lipschitz, so that small perturbations of original points do not cause large perturbations of the resulting clusters. It should also be such that if the original cloud happens to consist of k or fewer points, those same points are returned. These two properties are captured by the concept of a Lipschitz retract. This project advanced the understanding of Lipschitz retracts between finite subset spaces: they exist in spaces of zero curvature (such as a flat plane) or negative curvature (such as a saddle-shaped surface), but not in spaces of positive curvature (such as a sphere). Moreover, an explicit construction of such retracts was obtained.

 

Another common theme in the geometry of metric spaces is that the distance between two points need not be equal to the length of the shortest path between them. We observe this in everyday life by noting that the straight-line distance ("as the crow flies") does not match the walking or driving distance. A space in which the shortest-path distance is comparable to the straight-line distance is called quasiconvex. The quasiconvexity is a desirable feature of a metric space. One of the outcomes of this project is that removing a set of finite length from the plane preserves its quasiconvexity, provided that the removed set is dust-like, i.e, does not contain any nontrivial connected subsets. This settled a question raised in 2008 by Hakobyan and Herron.     

 

Broader Impacts

One of the results of this project already found an unexpected application in Mathematical Physics, providing a crucial element for the paper "A Sharp Upper Bound on the Spectral Gap for Graphene Quantum Dots" by Vladimir Lotoreichik and Thomas Ourmi?res-Bonafos (2019). The studies of extensions of Lipschitz maps benefit theoretical computer science, specifically in the area of Nonlinear Dimension Reduction, which concerns the transformations of a high-dimensional point cloud into a lower-dimensional space.   

 

The Principal Investigator was engaged in mentoring activities on both undergraduate and graduate level throughout the project. They included independent study courses, informal guided reading, undergraduate research projects, PhD thesis supervision, academic advising, Putnam team training, Undergraduate Math Club organization. In total, four PhD students were engaged in research during the project. Two of them graduated in 2015 and 2016, one is expected to graduate in 2020, and one is in early stages of research work. Some of the graduate students already began to contribute to mathematical community with their research publications. The undergraduate mentees participated in conferences, gave presentations at locally organized events, obtained internal funding for summer research projects, and participated in panel discussions for broader undergraduate audience together with the Principal Investigator.
